comments.commentBody: In other words, McCann, freedom of speech and democratic government are not for you. Then how can you claim to be an American when you reject some very basic principles that we stand for?

(cont.) It is inversely proportional the probability that the U.S. will collapse.

Therefore, the reason that money can't be derived from either macro or micro economics is because money is a barter commodity, which the sovereign transform into money by the political power of his fiat. The value of money is not as a good or a commodity but is the result of the political authority of the sovereign, whose fiat decrees it to be a medium of exchange and a unit of value. The status of fiat currency as money is based on the sovereign's decree, and its value of money depends on the sovereign's political power.

I'll leave the equations for you as an exercise. Turn in your work by Monday, 18 February 2015, on this blog. There will be extra credit for a scenario, with supporting equations, on how the Eurozone's disintegration, starting with the exit of Greece from the Eurozone, would affect the value of the euro, showing the range of probability of the Eurozone's collapse at which the euro become unstable and the range of probability at which the euro's value will become virtually zero.

Next, we will take up a system of differential equations, but with constraints on the political outcomes, for various scenarios of Eurozone's collapse, solving that system for probability of those various scenarios.

To clarify my point on why the origin of money's value can't be explained by economics is that money, in the origin of its value, isn't an economic phenomena; it is a political one. Once the sovereign's decree that it shall be a medium of exchange and a unit of value transforms a barter commodity into money, the real value that money has is that decree and that it is the manifestation of the sovereign's police power to enforce and regulate trades in the market for goods, services, and debts.

But money's value as money is fragile, for it depends on the public's faith in the sovereign's power, stability, and on his/its ability to manage monetary policy to maintain money's value, specifically so that inflation or deflation is constrained within reasonable bounds over at least the long-run. If there is any doubt about the sovereign's ability to enforce in trade and transactions its decree that a commodity will be the medium of exchange and a unit of value and/or in the sovereign's ability to maintain money's value, then the value of that commodity as money becomes unstable and may proceed to collapse.

If the Eurozone's instant troubles cause the public to lose faith in the euro as money, e.g., as was true for Weimar Republic or Confederate dollars at the end of the Civil War, the euro will provide the latest natural experiment in to prove that money's value is the sovereign's decree that it is money and the public's faith in the power of that decree.

Come on Paul; you guys, the macro-economists, can figure out why people value money, which is usually just a piece of paper with writing and a pretty design on it, in terms of real goods and bonds. That piece of paper is valued because the sovereign, the person of entity with the monopoly of power, declares by his/its fiat that the pieces of paper and coin in various denomination is and shall be the medium of exchange and unit of value and can enforce his decree making those pretty pieces of paper the exclusive commodity that is a medium of exchange and until of value in his/its courts and with his/its police power.That's it.

Try this thought experiment take euros and imagine first that markets (goods, bonds, etc.) become aware that the Eurozone, the sovereign, is likely to breakup and collapse. What then is the value of euros in exchange for goods, services, and debt denominated in euros? It is inversely proportional to the probability that the Eurozone will cease to be: As the probability of the Eurozone's collapse increases, the value of the euro falls, until in some region of highly probability of the Eurozone's collapse, euros become worthless.

Imagine a second case, where the Eurozone weathers the instant crisis and form a unitary government, which corrects all of the euro's theoretical defects, and the Eurozone is thriving, but the United States is disintegrating. What is the value of dollars in terms of the euro? (cont.)

Not sure which is the "worse" penalty, solitary confinement for extended periods or death. I don't particularly agree with the death penalty, but solitary is pretty cruel too. Plus, if guys like Kulklinski are spared by virtue of their resident state, should others unfortunate enough to live in "death" states be executed. Seems inconsistent.
Then there is the "religious" angle. As a so called "christian" country is execution by any means justified? Is Jesus to be the role model for executions? Or should we just follow his teachings, which are a tad more lenient.
I think at this juncture we have witnessed sufficient alternatives to capital punishment. Maybe its time to "federalize" the process, make it uniform, throughout the country, spare lives and use our capitalistic instincts ( which has already begun I guess) in the area of crime and punishment.

Are you implying that having gay parents would be harmful to a child?
Studies of this subject have shown that children thrive with good parents whether they are gay or straight.
Gays are not pedophiles any more than straights are pedophiles.
Gayness is not infectious. A straight person is born straight and a gay person is born gay.
Very logical, but the ones responsible for overseeing her are the Supreme Court. Anyone who thinks she messed up has to complain to them.

Wow, it looks like you don't value marriage very much at all if you honestly can endorse two people entering a life-long commitment without any attraction for one another.  Personally, I can't imagine being doomed to live a life with someone I don't love or someone who doesn't make my heart race each and every time I'm with them.  Guess that's a foreign concept to people like you.
Ron Paul is the archetype.
When asked to name their greatest concerns, I wonder how many of the general public would place auditing the Fed as a high priority?

I agree Mark.
Transparency, accountability, and responsibility are fundamental characteristics that government agencies and departments are obligated to possess in order to effectively serve the American people.

Now that the Fed's mandate is goosing the stock market in a straight 30 degree growth line over 6 years despite poor economic fundamentals, it’s time we lift the veil from this mammoth organization and understand, why they must fight it. What are they hiding?

To achieve real transparency, we need a full audit of the Fed – no exceptions. Just as, to achieve real accountability, we need a full audit of the Department of Defense – no exceptions.

From my years of experience as an auditor, it is a qualified opinion that the Fed is a 'going concern and criminal enterprise' chartered by another one, Congress.

(I am former Arthur Andersen and KPMG, with a MBA in Finance (Honors) and I fully endorse this message).
Moore's only delaying the inevitable. And history won't look kindly upon him.
Inflation is good for debtors and bad for creditors.  It's obvious if you think about it.
Audit the Department of Defense!

So have a third party do the audit. If there is nothing to hide then why the fuss. The Federal Reserve isn't independent. Many on the board also run the banks. Jamie Dimon is on the Federal Reserve of New York Board. How much has JP Morgan paid in fines this year for nefarious activities. With board members like that I think the Fed should be audited.

Oh please, give us all on this thread a break. Nobody, outside of delusional social conservatives, will view this as "the new Roe v Wade." As much as they (and you, apparently) wish to hold on to cherished discrimnatory prejudices and unconstitutional laws, that ship has sailed already and the sooner everyone realizes that, the better. What other arguments are there left to make? State after state have come up with essentially the same drivel as legal argument and had those arguments rejected over and over and over again.

The GOP can keep beating this dead horse, but for the fact is the majority of the public has moved on already.

I guess that "regular couples" that planned to wed soon are out of luck.

That will not sit well with those couples who planned their weddings a year or so ago. Closing the Probate Court is an extreme measure.
Actually that vote was during the primary season when only about 30% of your population turns out. So that 82% number is bogus.
Um, and what exactly would that entail, giving up pine planks?

It amazes me how many people, especially those who claim to be Christians, fail to understand the Golden Rule:  do unto others as you would have done unto you.  Seems pretty straight forward.  Would you want a majority of people voting on whether you should be entitled to full citizenship and respect for your relationships?  I really think you wouldn't want that...and nor do GLBT people.

Quilty: You say "Healthcare providers have financial incentives. Patients may even have financial incentives, such as a reason for taking time off from work without penalty." Is this your own theory or do you know therapists personally?

You state this as if you think these are major motivators for therapists. I can assure you (after being in the field for 30+ years) that most are NOT primarily motivated by money. They're generally motivated by the desire to help people, curiosity about the human mind, other less tanglible values. Most of my colleagues, talented New York therapists, are not fabulously weathy; most make less than their patients. Many therapists routinely lower fees, especially if an established patient has a crisis (such as losing a job).

If someone is mostly motivated by financial incentives, he/she chooses a much more lucrative field requiring little to no advanced education (MA, MD, PhD), exams/certifications, continuing ed costs. all out of pocket.

When one uses the primary criteria of "financial incentive" it extends a business (profit) model and projects it on others who do not primarily share these values. Of course, there are some greedy practioners. Most therapists want to make a decent living but they more want to help their patients get well.

Your comment that "patients may even have financial incentives" is absurd and reductionistic. I have never heard of a patient who sees a therapist to "take time off from work without penalty."
This is how I feel-> http://youtu.be/ZGes7FDmHAM
Friend.  Your argument was made both about slavery and about Jim Crow.  Sorry, individual freedom is not up for a vote.

How many conspiracy theories when it comes to the banking industry have become conspiracy fact? Let's count them...

1.) Conspiracy theory- Interests rates are manipulated.
Conspiracy fact- LIBOR scandal
2.) Conspiracy theory- foreign exchange rates manipulated
Conspiracy fact- FOREX scandal
3.) Conspiracy theory- precious metal prices manipulated
Conspiracy fact- metal prices set
4.) Conspiracy theory- federal reserve propping up stock market
Conspiracy fact-Federal Reserve buys stock
5.) Conspiracy theory- Federal Reserve QE aggravates inequality
Conspiracy fact- Yellen notes inequality QE ends
6.) Conspiracy theory- nations want gold returned from Fed
Conspiracy fact- Germany, Netherlands etc. get gold back
7.) Conspiracy theory- Fed no longer has 60 tons of America's gold
Conspiracy fact- only an audit can confirm so let's see it.

What if you put the question of whether mixed race marriages should be allowed -would that be a reasonable issue to put before the voters?  Or whether blacks could be restricted from voting? Or whether homosexuality should be illegal? These questions may sound ridiculous but it's not difficult to imagine that a majority of Alabama voters might vote in favor of these issues today or in the recent past.  The important factor here is that for many issues the will of the majority has to be tempered by the rights of individuals to live their lives.  This is especially true for acts that have no real consequences for others, like marriage, and that are only opposed out of spite, bigotry, hatred or blind traditionalism.
So what. If the Fed has nothing to hide then conduct the audit. Let a public official see and test the gold bars that belongs to the American public and be done with it.
Good luck -you ever seen anything made or grown in Alabama?
